title-group.article-title: A Quarter Century of APOE and Alzheimer’s Disease: Progress to Date and the Path Forward

contrib-group.aff: Department of Neurology and Neurological Sciences, FIND Lab, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, 94304, USA

fn.p: The authors declare no competing interests.

abstract.p: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is considered a polygenic disorder. This view is clouded, however, by lingering uncertainty over how to treat the quasi “monogenic” role of apolipoprotein E (APOE). The APOE4 allele is not only the strongest genetic risk factor for AD, it also affects risk for cardiovascular disease, stroke, and other neurodegenerative disorders. This review, based mostly on data from human studies, ranges across a variety of APOE-related pathologies, touching on evolutionary genetics and risk mitigation by ethnicity and sex. The authors also address one of the most fundamental question pertaining to APOE4 and AD: Does APOE4 increase AD risk via a loss- or gain-of-function? The answer will be of the utmost importance in guiding future research in AD.

abstract.title: In brief
abstract.p: Does APOE4 increase risk for Alzheimer’s disease via a gain- or loss-of-function? Belloy, et al., focusing on human data, examine critical issues like pleiotropy, sex, and ancestral background, to address this fundamental question.
